```
- name: install things

```

comments.body:
Remark: with regexp factored out this could become just
```python
from functools import partial
...
_is_vcs_url = partial(re.match, _VCS_RE)
"""Test whether a name is package name or version specifier."""
```

(But I bet Toshio would blame it for being unreadable, so don't do it :smile:)
I wouldn't write a function which was itself a single function call ;-)

> "~="

I've never heard of it. What is the source of such an assumption?
I saw it here https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#version-specifiers, and it's supported by `pip`.
Maybe `DistributionPackage`?
I'd probably move it to the initializer: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/48095#issuecomment-436315372
Make sense. Will do.

Now I remember. It cannot be done in the initializer, because package name isn't split from the version there, so that means it would canonicalize the `name=version`, which isn't what we want. Anyway it's only needed here so it's fine that it stays.

comments.body: Which version of pip did this appear in?
Tbh I have no idea. This is where I found it https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/. I also found the exact code in pip, but since this a few months ago, I forgot :)
Well, the reason I'm asking is that by using something which is present on only new envs you're adding an implicit dependency and we have to maintain backwards compatibility we committed to maintain.
I don't think we should be referencing a private attribute/variable here in any case.  We have no guarantee that it will exist in any future release either.
Right, that too. Recently, pip moved all of "seemingly public" modules under explicit "_internal" package to make it clear that users ain't supposed to abuse those.

I don't understand how is this not backward compatible even if older pip versions don't canonicalize package names. For example currently on pip it's not possible to create two different packages with these names:
* `Junit-XML`
* `junit-xml`
* `junit.xml`

This is a limitation of https://pypi.org/, so you will be able to have only one of those packages. I even did a fast test by counting the number of packages, and than canonicalizing their names and counting them again:
```
# Total number of packages
$ curl -s https://pypi.org/simple/ | grep -c href=
157503

# Number of packages after canonicalization
$ curl -s https://pypi.org/simple/ | grep href= | sed -r 's#[^"]+"/simple/([^/]+)/.*#\1#g' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]' | sort | wc -l
157503
```
As you can see it's the same number of packages.

That means even if we canonicalize names on older versions, nothing will change.
I'm talking about `ImportError`.
@webknjaz sorry, but I don't understand about what ImportError are you talking about? I didn't use any imports in this PR as far as I can see.
Oh, I've got an impression that you're using pip's importables. In this case it's fine.
Shouldn't `.` and `-` be escaped properly?
Okay, I've checked docs and it seems fine here.

Neither of those are special characters in python so they don't have to be escaped for python strings.  Inside of a character class regex characters like ```.``` don't have to be escaped because they don't have special meaning there. ```-``` doesn't have to be escaped in a character class as long as it is the first character in the character class.
Why does it require `to_native` in here?
